api: A way for different programs to talk to each other and share data
endpoint: A specific URL where your app can send or receive data
skeleton loader: A placeholder animation that shows while content is loading
skeleton: A placeholder animation that shows while content is loading
component: A reusable piece of UI code, like a building block
props: Data you pass into a component to customize how it works
state: Data that can change over time in your app
hook: A special function in React that adds extra powers to components
middleware: Code that runs between a request and response, like a checkpoint
async: Code that runs in the background without blocking other tasks
promise: A way to handle code that takes time to finish, like fetching data
callback: A function that runs after another function finishes
cors: Security rules that control which websites can access your data
jwt: A secure way to verify who someone is without passwords
oauth: A way to let users log in using Google, Facebook, etc.
rest api: A simple way to send and receive data using URLs
graphql: A flexible way to ask for exactly the data you need
websocket: A two-way connection that lets your app talk to a server in real-time
orm: A tool that lets you work with databases using regular code instead of SQL
migration: A step-by-step record of changes to your database structure
cache: Storing data temporarily so you don't have to fetch it again
cdn: A network of servers around the world that delivers your files faster
ssr: Server-Side Rendering - building web pages on the server before sending them
spa: Single-Page App - a website that feels like a desktop app
dom: The browser's representation of your webpage that you can change with code
virtual dom: A lightweight copy of the webpage used to make updates faster
webpack: A tool that bundles all your code files into one optimized package
babel: A tool that translates modern JavaScript into older versions for compatibility
typescript: JavaScript with type checking to catch errors before running code
linter: A tool that checks your code for mistakes and style issues
git: A system for tracking changes to your code over time
branch: A separate version of your code where you can experiment safely
commit: Saving a snapshot of your code changes with a description
pull request: Asking teammates to review and merge your code changes
merge conflict: When two people change the same code and Git needs help deciding which to keep
docker: A way to package your app with everything it needs to run anywhere
container: A lightweight box that holds your app and its dependencies
kubernetes: A system for managing and running many containers at once
ci/cd: Automatically testing and deploying your code when you make changes
env variable: Secret configuration values stored outside your code
environment: A place where your code runs, like 'development' or 'production'
localhost: Your own computer acting as a web server for testing
port: A numbered door on your computer where a program listens for connections
ssl: Security that encrypts data traveling between your app and users
https: The secure version of HTTP that encrypts website traffic
dns: The system that converts website names into computer addresses
ip address: A unique number that identifies a computer on the internet
cloud: Computers and storage you rent on the internet instead of owning
serverless: Running code without managing servers - the cloud does it for you
lambda: A small piece of code that runs in the cloud when triggered
database: An organized place to store and find data
sql: A language for asking databases questions and getting data back
nosql: A flexible type of database that stores data without strict rules
json: A simple way to structure data using brackets and colons
xml: An older way to structure data using tags, like HTML
regex: A pattern-matching language for finding text that matches rules
encryption: Scrambling data so only authorized people can read it
hash: A one-way scramble of data, useful for passwords
salt: Random data added before hashing to make it more secure
token: A temporary password that proves you're logged in
session: Keeping track of a user while they use your app
cookie: A small piece of data stored in the user's browser
localstorage: A place in the browser to save data that persists between visits
responsive design: Making websites look good on phones, tablets, and computers
mobile-first: Designing for phones first, then adapting to bigger screens
breakpoint: A screen size where your layout changes to fit better
grid: A layout system for arranging items in rows and columns
flexbox: A layout system for arranging items in a flexible way
css: The language that controls how websites look
sass: A more powerful version of CSS with variables and functions
tailwind: A CSS framework using small utility classes instead of custom styles
bootstrap: A popular CSS framework with pre-made components
polyfill: Code that adds modern features to older browsers
bundler: A tool that combines all your code files into one
minify: Removing unnecessary characters from code to make it smaller
tree shaking: Removing unused code from your final bundle
lazy loading: Loading parts of your app only when needed, not all at once
code splitting: Breaking your code into chunks that load separately
hot reload: Instantly seeing code changes without refreshing the page
debugging: Finding and fixing errors in your code
console: A place in your browser where you can see messages and errors
stack trace: A list showing where an error happened in your code
exception: An error that stops your code from running normally
undefined: A variable that hasn't been given a value yet
array: A list of items stored in order
object: A collection of related data stored as key-value pairs
function: A reusable block of code that performs a specific task
class: A blueprint for creating objects with similar properties
constructor: A special function that creates and sets up new objects
inheritance: When one class gets features from another class
interface: A contract that defines what properties an object must have
dependency: Code written by someone else that your project needs to work
package: A bundle of reusable code you can add to your project
npm: A tool for installing and managing JavaScript packages
yarn: An alternative to npm for managing packages
node: JavaScript that runs on computers instead of browsers
framework: A complete toolkit with everything you need to build an app
library: A collection of useful code functions you can use
boilerplate: Template code that's the same in every project
scaffold: Automatically generating the basic structure of a project
monorepo: Storing multiple related projects in one repository
microservice: Breaking an app into small, independent services
monolith: An app where all the code is in one big project
deployment: Putting your app on the internet where users can access it
build: Preparing your code to run in production
production: The live version of your app that real users see
staging: A copy of production used for final testing before release
rollback: Reverting to a previous version when something breaks
version: A numbered release of your code, like 1.0 or 2.5
changelog: A list of what changed in each version
deprecate: Marking old code as outdated and planning to remove it
legacy code: Old code that still works but needs updating
refactor: Improving code without changing what it does
tech debt: Shortcuts taken now that will need fixing later
mvp: Minimum Viable Product - the simplest version that works
agile: A flexible way of building software in small iterations
sprint: A short period (usually 2 weeks) focused on specific tasks
backlog: A list of features waiting to be built
user story: A description of a feature from the user's perspective
acceptance criteria: Rules that define when a feature is done correctly
